qas.question: Are there studies on Hispanic-American language?

answers.text: Calvin Veltman undertook, for the National Center for Education Statistics and for the Hispanic Policy Development Project

qas.question: What is Calvin Veltman' study about?

answers.text: the most complete study of English language adoption by Hispanophone immigrants
high bilingualism rates and subsequent adoption of English as the preferred language of Hispanics, particularly by the young and the native-born.

qas.question: Is Calvin Veltman' relevant to today's Hispanic Americans?

answers.text: his study based itself upon a large 1976 sample from the Bureau of the Census (which has not been repeated),

qas.question: Are there other similar findings similar to Calvin Veltman' for the modern age?

answers.text: data from the 1990 Census tend to confirm the great Anglicization of the US Hispanic American origin population.

qas.question: Who undertook the most complete study of Hispanic language adoption?
What demographics did Veltman exclude from the study?
Data from which census confirms the great Anglicization of the billingual population?
What is the preferred language of Hispanophone immigrants?
How many generations are required for a Native American to assimilate?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Calvin Veltman<b5_0/> undertook, for the National Center for Education Statistics and for the Hispanic Policy Development Project<a0_0/>, <a1_0>the most complete study of English language adoption by Hispanophone immigrants<a1_0/>. Mr Veltman's language shift studies document <a2_0>high bilingualism rates and subsequent adoption of <b8_0>English<b8_0/> as the preferred language of Hispanics, particularly by <b6_0>the young and the native-born<b6_0/>.<a2_0/> The complete set of these studies' demographic projections postulates the near-complete assimilation of a given Hispanophone immigrant cohort within <b9_0>two<b9_0/> generations. Although <a3_0>his study based itself upon a large 1976 sample from the Bureau of the Census (which has not been repeated),<a3_0/> <a4_0>data from the <b7_0>1990 Census<b7_0/> tend to confirm the great Anglicization of the US Hispanic American origin population.
